page.title: Motivation
page.markdown:
##The three main goals of this course are:
- Gain experience with proofs. - Have fun proving statements about real numbers, functions, and limits. - Formalize proofs in the Lean proof assistant.. (it's more addictive than sudoku - really!)

html.p: If you're investing money, then perhaps you'd like to know that your strategies are sound and that the calculated probabilities of certain events are meaningful. The tools you learn in this course will prepare you for understanding metric spaces, which are the foundation of probability and statistics. (fact check)

Encryption is woven through every part of our online world to ensure the security of nations and personal privacy. Without proofs from number theory, we wouldn't be able to rely on programs to keep our secrets safe.

Numerical analysis is used to make guarantees about the errors that computers introduce into important calculations, such as those guiding spacecraft to the moon, Mars, and beyond. Proofs help scientists more reliably make discoveries.

Proof assistants such as Lean enable us to verify and tinker with our reasoning with unparalleled guarantees with relying on peer consensus. The quick feedback loop a proof assistant provides means that you can learn to prove on your own!

page.title: Sets Intro

html.def: A set is a collection of objects called elements or members of that set. The empty set (denoted `\emptyset`) is the set with no elements.

page.html:
We want to relate different sets, and thus we get the following notation/definitions:
(todo: need to clean up these relations)
1. The set `A` is a subset of `B`, if every element of `A` is in `B`. Given `A \subset B`, if `a \in A \implies a \in B`.
2. Two sets `A` and `B` are equal, `A = B`, if `A \subset B` and `B \subset A `.
3. A set `A` is a proper subset of `B`, `A\subsetneq B` if `A \subset B` and `A\neq B`.

page.title: Anatomy of implication
page.html:
2.3: Implications by Harris Kwong
It is essential fully understand logical implication means, and how it is used in logic and math.
You are a nuclear bomb technician.
You are at a test site in Nevada, standing directly under an atomic bomb.
Please consider the following:
"If the bomb explodes then you will die instantly"
That statement is designed to be undeniable, and it has the form:
\[ A \implies B \]
The converse of `A \implies B \quad` is `\quad B \implies A`
"if you die instantly then the bomb explodes"
That's false, the detonator is controlled by professionals who are not influenced by your health
The inverse of `A \implies B \quad` is `\quad \neg A \implies \neg B`
"If the bomb does not explode then you will not die instantly ."
Is that necessarily true? No, you could have a heart attack, a stroke or pick your poison. There's lots of ways to drop dead that have nothing to do with the bomb.
The contrapositive of `A \implies B \quad` is `\quad \neg B \implies \neg A`
"if you do not die instantly then the bomb did not explode"
Is that necessarily true? YES! Since you're still standing there, then the bomb most definitely did not go off!

page.title: Set builder notation
page.markdown:
One way to describe a set is using "set-builder notation". We write
\[ \{x \in A \mid P(x)\} \quad \text{or} \quad \{x\mid P(x)\} \]
to mean "all `x \in A` that satisfies property `P(x)`". One example of this would be `\{ x \mid x\ \text{is an even number} \}`. There are a few key sets that we will use throughout this class:
- `\mathbb{N}`, The set of natural numbers:` \{1,2,3,4,\dots\} ` - `\mathbb{Z}`, The set of integers: ` \{0, 1, -1, 2, -2, 3, -3, \dots\} ` - `\mathbb{Q}`, The set of rational numbers:` \{\frac{m}{n} \mid m,n\in \mathbb{Z} \land n\neq 0\} ` - `\mathbb{R}`, The set of real numbers.

page.title: More about sets
page.html:
In the meantime, let's continue our study of sets and proof methods. Given sets `A` and `B`, we have the following definitions:
The intersection of `A` and `B` is the set `A \cap B = \{x\mid x\in A \land x\in B\}.` The union of `A` and `B` is the set `A \cup B = \{x\mid x\in A \lor x\in B\}.` The set difference of `A` and `B` is the set `A \setminus B = \{x\in A \mid x\notin B\}.` The complement of `A` is the set `A^c = \{x \mid x\notin A\}` `A` and `B` are disjoint if `A\cap B = \emptyset`

page.title: De Morgan's Laws
page.theorem: If `A,B,C` are sets then \begin{align} (B\cup C)^c &= B^c \cap C^c \\ \\ (B\cap C)^c &= B^c \cup C^c \\ \\ A \setminus (B \cup C) &= (A\setminus B) \cap (A\setminus C) \\ \\ A \setminus (B \cap C) &= (A\setminus B) \cup (A\setminus C) \\ \end{align}

mchoice.label: Given two sets `T` and `U`, please select the definition of `T = U`

proof.p:
Let `B`, `C` be sets. We are proving,
\[ ( B \cup C )^c = (B^c \cap C^c) \]
Start by rewriting the equality in terms of its definition,
\[ (B \cup C)^c \subset ( B^c \cap C^c ) \quad \text{and} \quad (B^c \cap C^c)^c \subset ( B \cup C )^c \]
For the first inclusion, ` (B \cup C)^c \subset ( B^c \cap C^c ) `.

How is induction used in practice? When we want to prove some statement,
\[ \forall n \in \mathbb{N}, \quad P(n)\ \text{is true}. \]
Induction requires two smaller proofs:

tr.td: More involved, need to prove ` P(m) \implies P(m + 1) `

page.title: Another induction example
page.theorem:
For this proposition:
\[ P(n) := (1+c)^n \ge 1 + nc. \]
Let's prove the following theorem,
If ` c \ge -1 `, then ` P(n) ` is true ` \forall n \in \mathbb{N}. `

proof.p: Check ` P(1) `: if ` c \ge -1 `, then ` P(1) ` is true.

We rewrite ` P(1) ` with the definition of ` P ` to get,
\[ (1+c)^1 \ge 1 + 1 \cdot c \]
Then evaluate with the exponential and multiplicative identities to find,
\[ 1 + c = 1 + c \]
which is true by the reflexive property of equality, therefore the base case is proven. Onto the inductive step!

html.proof:
We've proven the base case `P(1)`. Next the goal is to prove that `P(m) \implies P(m+1)` so we can construct a chain of implications
\begin{align} P(1) &\implies P(2) \\ &\implies P(3) \\ &\implies \vdots \\ &\implies P(n-1) \\ &\implies P(n) \\ \end{align}
Here we go!
\[ P(m) \implies P(m+1) \]
Rewrite `P` to get:
\[ (1 + c)^m \ge 1 + mc \implies (1 + c)^{(m+1)} \ge 1 + (m+1)\cdot c \]
We have,
\begin{align} (1+c)^{m+1} &= (1+c)(1+c)^m \\ &\ge (1+c)(1 + mc) \tag{\( \star_1 \)}\\ &= 1 + mc + c + mc^2 \\ &= 1 + (m+1)c + mc^2 \\ &\ge 1 + (m+1)c \tag{\( \star_2 \)}, \end{align}
multiply both sides of the antecendent `P(m)` by `(1+c)` `mc^2` is non-negative, so dropping it supports the inequality.
`P(m + 1)` unfolds to the final right hand side of the chain,
\[ (1+c)^{m+1} \ge 1 + (m+1)c \]
html.p: Let's take a look at the logic underpinning the overall reasoning here, in four steps to determine the truth of the implication.

Step 1 : Establish the implication
\[ P(m) \implies P(m+1) \]
Step 2 : Assume `P(m)` because it will be rooted in the base case.
\[ \text{True} \implies P(m+1) \]
Step 3 The inductive step shows that no matter which `P(m)` is true, the next, `P(m+1)` is also true. So, since the base case `P(1)` is proven to be true, the inductive step is used to assert `P(2)`.

Next, since `P(2)` is now proven to be true as well, the inductive step is used again to assert `P(3)`, and so on, forever.
\[ \text{True} \implies \text{True} \]
step 4 : From formal logic, the truth table:
`a` `b` `a \implies b`
`T` `T` `T`
`T` `F` `F`
`F` `T` `T`
`F` `F` `T`
\[ \underbrace{ \text{True} \implies \text{True} }_{\text{entire implication evaluates to True}} \]
\begin{align} P(1) \implies P(2) \implies P(2) \implies \cdots \implies P(n-1) &\implies P(n) \\ \text{True} \implies P(2) \implies P(3) \implies \cdots \implies P(n-1) &\implies P(n) \\ \text{True} \implies P(3) \implies \cdots \implies P(n-1) &\implies P(n) \\ \text{True} \implies \cdots \implies P(n-1) &\implies P(n) \\ \text{True} \implies P(n-1) &\implies P(n) \\ \text{True} &\implies P(n) \\ \text{True} \\ \end{align}
By induction, `\forall n, P(n)` holds `\quad \square`
